p: Although the proportion of seropositivity depends on the diagnostic method used, it also relies on study planning; if a serosurvey is conducted long after the end of an outbreak, the signal for the antibodies may be lower than in a study conducted close to the end of an outbreak. Our results indicate that DENV seroprevalence in the Americas was higher than that in Asia, which is surprising because dengue has been endemic in Southeast Asia for decades [ 183], and the Asian burden, including the Western Pacific, accounted for nearly 75% of the global burden worldwide [ 184]. Analysis revealed that studies conducted in the Americas were performed significantly more frequently in an outbreak or post-outbreak context (p<0.01) via IgM ELISA, which could explain the discrepancy between America and Asia.
